stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data from 0800 to 1100. Which finding most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions?

options.text: Increase in PR interval from 0.24 seconds at 0800 to 0.28 seconds at 1100.
Decrease in heart rate from 52 bpm at 0800 to 68 bpm at 1100.
Increase in serum digoxin level from 1.8 ng/mL at 0800 to 2.2 ng/mL at 1100.
Appearance of frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) on the ECG at 1100.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 0800: Client reports nausea and blurred vision. ECG shows prolonged PR interval and bradycardia. Digoxin level drawn. Hold digoxin as prescribed. Notify MD. 0900: MD order received: Administer Digoxin Immune Fab (Digibind). Digibind initiated per protocol. Monitor vital signs and ECG closely. 1000: Patient denies nausea. Vision improving. 1100: Repeat ECG performed. Patient resting comfortably.

tabs.title: Orders
tabs.content:
• Hold Digoxin if HR < 60 bpm
  • Digoxin Immune Fab (Digibind) IV per protocol
  • Monitor ECG continuously
  • Repeat Digoxin level in 3 hours

rationale.correctRationale: A decrease in heart rate towards a normal range after administration of Digoxin Immune Fab (Digibind) indicates a therapeutic response. Digoxin toxicity often manifests as bradycardia. An increase in heart rate from 52 bpm to 68 bpm suggests the Digibind is effectively neutralizing the digoxin.
incorrectRationales: An increase in the PR interval indicates worsening digoxin effect, not a therapeutic response. Digoxin toxicity prolongs the PR interval.
An increase in the serum digoxin level indicates worsening toxicity, not a therapeutic response. The goal of Digibind is to neutralize digoxin, although serum levels may still appear elevated.
The appearance of PVCs indicates worsening digoxin toxicity. PVCs are a common dysrhythmia associated with digoxin toxicity.
rationale.clinicalPearls: Digoxin toxicity can present with a variety of symptoms, including bradycardia, visual disturbances (blurred vision, yellow halos), nausea, vomiting, and ECG changes such as prolonged PR interval, ST depression, and arrhythmias. Digoxin levels should be monitored closely, and Digibind is the antidote for severe toxicity.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may incorrectly assume that any change in heart rate is positive, without considering the context of digoxin toxicity and the desired therapeutic outcome of Digibind. They may also focus on the increasing digoxin level without understanding that Digibind binds to digoxin, making it inactive but not necessarily lowering the measured serum level immediately.
rationale.mnemonic: Bradycardia and visual disturbances signal potential 'Digi-toxicity'. Remember to check the 'Digi' level and ECG!
